title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It amends the findings section of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act" acknowledges the risks faced by homeless youth, emphasizing the need for temporary shelter and services. It highlights the responsibility of the Federal Government to address the issue on a national level and develop effective care systems. The "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act" aims to develop a comprehensive system of care for runaway and homeless youth, including preventive services, shelter options, education, job skills training, and employment opportunities. Improved coordination among Federal programs is crucial for a long-term strategy to meet the needs of this population. The "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act" focuses on providing comprehensive care for runaway and homeless youth, including services like shelter, education, and job training. Recent amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act include changes to grant programs, services provided, and eligibility provisions. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change eligibility provisions, recognize state laws on capacity limitations for youth centers, and address maternity group homes. SEC. 107 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include maternity group homes and define them as transitional living arrangements for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills. SEC. 108 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to extend shelter eligibility for youth under 18 until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the initial 540-day period. SEC. 109 updates coordination assurances for educational services for runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements for program implementation. SEC. 110 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends Section 322(a) to include coordination of services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to provide educational information to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 111 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends Section 322(a)(7) to require the development of a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs for homeless youth with the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under the Act. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment to a section heading. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to set an age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter in a center under part A, not more than 18 years of age. Authorization of appropriations is also addressed. SEC. 117 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act authorizes appropriations for fiscal years 2004-2008. Part E funding is adjusted, and the allocation for Part B is modified. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 mandates a study on housing outcomes for youth exiting programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 120 adds a new section restricting the use of funds under the Act. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to restrict the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is also amended to update findings. The Congress finds that thousands of children are abducted each year, putting them in grave danger. Missing children are at risk of harm and exploitation, requiring coordinated efforts from local, State, and Federal law enforcement. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a resource center in partnership with various government agencies. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various government agencies to locate missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a national and global network connecting with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL, and others to share information instantly with law enforcement worldwide. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of the reauthorization of programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act.
